dict.string: The BRAT is but a memory, but Subaru takes a second run at the car-based-pickup idea with the Baja. This one has four doors and doesn’t need the import-tax-evading seats in the bed, because it’s built at the company’s U.S. plant in Indiana (which is shared with Mitsubishi). Starting from a Legacy wagon, the Baja gets additional rear overhang sufficient to create a 42-inch cargo bed and visual hip waders in the form of plastic body cladding. To haul longer items, Subaru poked a hole in the back of the cab and offers a U-shaped fence that flips down onto the dropped tailgate. Clever, but the Baja lasts just four years.
